information:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 20 days. The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled for June 16, 2025, and today is May 27, 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: A man wins the 2025 Outstanding Chef award. The last two winners (2023 and 2024) were men, and over the last ten cycles, women have won 40% of the time while men won 60%.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: One of the male finalists for Outstanding Chef receives the award instead of Cassie Piuma. The judging panel's evaluation of culinary excellence, leadership, and impact leads them to select a male chef, continuing the pattern of the last two years.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cassie Piuma of Sarma wins the Outstanding Chef award. The judges recognize her culinary achievements and leadership, influenced by the Foundation's equity initiative and her standout credentials among the finalist pool.
forecast.rationale: The key evidence points to a probability below 50% but not trivially low. Cassie Piuma appears to be the only woman finalist for Outstanding Chef specifically (as opposed to regional Best Chef categories where multiple women are finalists). Historically, women have won this award 40% of the time over the last decade, establishing a meaningful baseline. However, the recent trend shows consecutive male winners in 2023 and 2024, creating negative momentum. The James Beard Foundation's post-2020 equity initiative has demonstrably increased female representation in regional Best Chef awards from 30% to 55% in 2024, showing the initiative has teeth. However, this impact may not translate fully to the prestigious Outstanding Chef category, which is more selective and traditionally less responsive to rapid change. If we assume approximately 5 finalists total, having one woman represents 20% of the pool. Given the 40% historical win rate for women and the equity push, this suggests when women are finalists, they punch above their proportional representation. The probability is not higher because: (1) recent momentum favors male winners, (2) only one female finalist limits odds, (3) the Outstanding Chef category may be slower to reflect equity changes than regional awards. The probability is not lower because: (1) the 40% historical rate is substantial, (2) the Foundation's equity commitment is real and impactful, (3) Piuma's finalist status indicates strong credentials. I would update higher if information showed multiple female finalists or evidence that the equity initiative specifically targeted national awards. I would update lower if details emerged suggesting the male finalists were particularly dominant or if historical patterns showed the award rarely goes to the same demographic profile in consecutive years (which appears not to be the case).

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will a woman win the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef?

Question background:
[Here Are the 2025 James Beard Awards Restaurant, Chef, and Media Award Finalists](https://www.eater.com/24398769/2025-james-beard-awards-restaurant-chef-finalists)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if a woman wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef.




Your research assistant's report says:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
